												Nostalgia really is a funny thing.I've been a Looking Glass Studios fan since the 90's with System Shock 2, and a Thief fan for a long time. Thief II: The Metal Age (the sequel to the critically-praised Thief: The Dark Project) brings players back into the world of master thief Garrett, this time with a bunch of new missions and antagonist in the form of Karras, the leader of the Mechanists.The one thing I loved most about this game was that the scale just felt bigger in (almost every way). While I still have an issue with the fact that roughly half the levels are strictly linear, the missions that open up to you (like "Stonemarket First Bank", "Life of the Party" and "Masks") offer a wide array of alternate routes and secret passages to accomplish your goals, as well as give a far grander sense of the City and the threat Karras poses to its inhabitants.Likewise, the variety of weapons and items you can acquire is great and allows for lots of experimentation, although (since I'm a purist) I still stuck to water arrows for the majority of the game.Admittedly, I found much more joy in the levels where I could pick off guards at will with hit-and-run tactics. I think it's fair to say that the AI in this game alternates between hypersensitive and woefully inept. When the guards aren't aggro-ing on you from far distances, they're complete morons in combat. It is exceptionally easy to take advantage of the combat system. When a sword-wielding guard runs at you, walk backwards and swing like mad, or circle-strafe and hit his back. Bow-wielders are an automatic win - just mash the attack button if you get one cornered. The only real challenge came from the Mechanist robots and groups of enemies, which sometimes stacked up in doors and got stuck or ran around the mansion in the "Masks" mission chasing me (all that was missing was the Benny Hill music).Likewise, the voice acting is either really good (in the case of Garrett's voice actor and some of the minor antagonists) or near-laughable (the nobles, who sound like they're reading from a script). I couldn't take Karras seriously as a villain because of his nasally voice, which made me laugh more than get freaked out whenever I heard his voice.I vaguely remembered a lot of buzz and praise for "Life of the Party", which sees Garrett take to the rooftops to rob every building in sight and infiltrate Karras' tower, Angelwatch - and that mission did not disappoint. Easily the best in the game, it had everything I consider to be so great about the genre - lots of expansive areas and alternate routes to take, lots of secrets and hidden goodies to find, great level design, the works. I wish more of the missions had those kinds of additional areas or features to make them worth replaying, because I didn't feel much compulsion to go back and do much besides replay the missions that were either "loot everything" or "steal and/or kill everything".All in all, though, Thief II is still a standout in the stealth genre. I haven't played Deadly Shadows yet (as of this writing), but the improvement in scope in this game makes me excited to see what's next.

												Thief II: The Metal Age sets the high water mark for stealth gaming.  Bar none.  No game before or since can compare to the immersiveness of this game and it's fine-tuned mechanics.  It manages to mix the fantasy, strategy and adventure aspects of the first with a more prescient storyline than the first Thief game.  The first game was an excellent stealth game that occasionally drifted too far into Tomb Raider territory with it's platformy style missions, devious traps and creature threats.  The fact that Eidos was the publisher of both Thief and Tomb Raider, and that one of the missions had you raiding an underground tomb frought with booby traps and monsters, ought to tell you something.  Thief 2 , thankfully, focuses on the strengths of the stealth system and makes that the core of the game and not just an aspect of it.  That's not to say you won't be jumping across ravines and encountering creatures, but the heist-pulling, pick-pocketing and blackjacking really comes into thier own in Thief 2.  I've read that the developers created the missions of the first game to suit the plot, while the missions of the second were produced first with the plot retrofitted.  In any case, the levels are larger and more complex than the first.The graphics had gotten a slight bump from the first game with higher poly models, better texturing and weather effects.  They even added dithering to the hardware renderer, which was a nice addition.  It did have the effect of dampening the deep shadows that were such a part of the first game, but it generally made the game more pleasing to the eye. The sound design is, again, excellent.  Sound propagation is one of the core facets of gameplay.  Listening to footsteps draw near or fade into the distance allow you to judge from your hiding place in the shadows whether or not you can risk stepping into lit areas.  Leaning against doors to listen to conversations or the presence of sounds in the next room allow you to determine if opening a door is wise or not.  Sound is fundamental to this game.  You will not be able to play this game successfully while blasting Megadeth or Slayer.  Just not happening.  And that's one of the things that makes this game so damn immersive.  You are literally concerned with the environment both visually and aurally at all times.  It sucks you in.  There are some new gadgets in this game.  Garrett lost an eye in the first game, and that has been replaced by a mechanical eye that can zoom in and out like a telescope.  A new object called the Scouting Orb allows you to take a peak over walls or around corners without exposing yourself.  There are also new potions and a new arrow:  the vine arrow.  Similar to the rope arrow, but it can "stick" to things rope arrows can't, like metal gratings.The design went from a predominantly dark age style steampunk in Thief 1 to a predominantly Victorian era style steampunk in Thief 2, in much of it's architecture.  Actually, art deco also makes an appearance as part of the design of buildings operated by a faction that's new to Thief 2, the Mechanists.   The European old world oozes in these games.  In fact, many of the textures from Thief 1 and Thief 2 were from photos of architecture taken by the developers while vacationing in Europe.   The overall design is pretty immaculate.  The first two Thief games share a cult status, along with System Shock2 (uses the same game engine and made by some of the same people), as games of remarkable vision and quality.  They are all lauded as excellent games by the gaming press and continue to make the top # lists.  The gameplay transcends gaming.  To play this game is to embark on an existential and  metaphysical experience.  This game seems to attract a higher-brow gaming audience.  There is a community forum that has been the stomping grounds of its players since the games were released.  They have created hundreds of fan missions to play; you can find it here:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/forum.phpHere you can get a community made patch that updates the rendering of the game and allows for some nice effects, like bloom, while also fixing a number of leftover bugs:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=131106Here you can get a high resolution patch that updates some models, textures and also adds a numbder of new effects to the game:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/showthread.php?t=144312Here you can read about and find fan missions to play:  http://www.ttlg.com/forums/forumdisplay.php?f=100

Thief II is a first-person stealth game realeased back in March of 2000. It's set in a city, aptly named The City, with a steampunk aesthetic. You play as Garrett, a thief with a wide assortment of tools, weapons, and gadgets to assist him. The minute you get in the first thing you'll probably do is change the controls. The default controls in this game are set up fairly differently than the average first-person game, but you'll have little-to-no trouble after setting them up. The graphics are pretty dated, even as far as 2000 is concerned.The stealth mechanics of Thief are much more interesting than the average stealth system, based more around light and sound as opposed to the cone of vision that other stealth games tend to employ. Garrett decides to wear his clogs on every mission, so stepping on stone makes you much more obvious than stepping on something like a rug, while stepping on tile is a death sentence. The light gem at the bottom of the screen lights up to tell you if you're being lit up by the light around you, or is dark to show that you're completely in the shadows. Very rarely do games use lighting and sound as effectively as Thief does here.The missions in the second Thief, as opposed to the original Thief, focus more around simple thievery instead of supernatural missions involving zombies and cultists. This is pretty subjective as to whether or not it's a pro or con, but I prefer the thievery. The original Thief is more of the same, but with more of the aforementioned zombies and cultists.ProsLighting and sound are both fantastic, easily some of the best, even today.Interesting stealth system, only game to use anything comparable is Mark of the Ninja.The atmosphere is so thick it could give you lung cancer.More focus on thieveryConsGraphics are pretty bad, even going back to 2000.Less than friendly to newer players, but not impossible to get intoLess focus on supernatural elements Final Thoughts:It's easily one of the best stealth games to date. The original is preferable if you want more of the zombies and similar stuff, and Deadly Shadows is a little more forgiving. Overall, I'd reccomend it to anyone looking for an extremely fun and unique stealth system that's rarely contested, even to this day.Rating: 9.5/10This review was written for and is published on the  Lit Reviews [LR] curator page.

												In 2016, it’s hard to say something about Thief II that hasn’t already been said. While Looking Glass Studios may have invented the modern stealth genre with Thief: The Dark Project, they perfected it with The Metal Age. This game’s innovative use of sound, sprawling level design, and impressive amount of player agency, create an experience that still immerses me to this day. Metal Age’s missions consist of sprawling sandboxes that allow the player to pursue objectives in whatever way they see fit. Along with the wide variety of tools spread throughout these missions (arrows, mines, bombs, etc.), there are practically infinite ways to traverse any given level. The levels themselves are set in a wide range of pseudo-medieval locations. As master thief Garrett, you’ll be robbing banks, breaking into manors, trailing people through city streets, and so much more. What's really incredible about The Metal Age is that in all of its vastness and player choice, it always manages to feel organic. During my time with Thief II, I never felt like a guy in his computer chair, I really felt like a master thief. This feeling of total immersion is greatly aided by Looking Glass‘ creative and dynamic use of sound. Your footsteps make different noises at different volumes depending on what surface you walk on. You can lean against doors to hear a muffled conversation between two guards. Every coin, key, chest, door, and ladder, makes appropriate jingles, creaks, and thumps. Eric Brosius’ composition work deserves special mention here. While not traditionally musical, Thief II‘s soundtrack expertly creates a nocturnal and ominous ambiance that never really comes to the forefront, but is always present.While it should be clear by this point that I consider Thief II to be a classic, I don’t believe it’s a perfect game. The Metal Age‘s most glaring flaw is in its visual fidelity. As a 3D game that's over a decade-and-a-half old, the graphics have aged somewhat unfavorably. Models are low-poly, with rigid animations and less than great texture work. While the dated graphics didn’t break my own personal immersion while playing, if you’re the kind of player who finds low-poly graphics to be distractingly jarring, this game may not pull you in as much as it has others. While not as much of a sticking point as the visuals, Thief II has one more notable flaw. The two missions prior to the final mission are practically identical, down to reusing the same map and having dangerously similar objectives. Neither mission is particularly bad, but the needless redundancy so close to the game’s conclusion may be frustrating for some players.That being said, these two flaws are relatively minor tarnishes on what I consider to be a nearly perfect game in terms of player choice, level design, and use of audio. Some classic games are recognized for their influence on the medium of games as a whole, whether it be a innovative mechanic, or even inventing an entire genre. However, we often return to these games and find them to be dated or unentertaining. Thief II: The Metal Age serves as a welcome exception to this trend, and has stood the test of time to become one of the greatest stealth games ever made.            Overall Score: 9/10+ Huge Levels+ Multiple Paths / Choices Through Missions+ Great Setting Variety+ Good use of Sound+ Highly Immersive- Dated Graphics- One Redundant Mission

												Thief II: The Metal Age is a 2000 stealth game, developed by the now-defunct Looking Glass Studios, the successor of the widely acclaimed yet underrated Thief The Dark Project (1998), considered by many as the pioneer of modern stealth game, released along other amazing stealth titles such as Tenchu and Metal Gear Solid.  Being the least known of those 3 (at least from my point of view), Thief, for me,  is the most advanced on how a sneaking game should be, and that’s coming from someone who don’t have nostalgia glasses attached at all.Dawn of The Metal Age You take the role of Garrett, the cynical, sarcastic, and somewhat selfish master thief, with his only goal is to steal enough goods to pay his rent. A pretty interesting hero (or antihero) in the get go isn’t he? That very attitude, skill, and notoriety is the source of the problem on both games. You start off by having a couple of disconnected missions, before the real problem takes off. Thief Gold (I’ll just call the first one Thief Gold from now on)  has a pacing issues in the first couple of missions, because they’re kind of a long ”introductory” missions. Setting up the Thief universe, Garrett as a character, and it’s gameplay mechanics, and then it becomes a bizarre and intense supernatural horror story. With all the universe building stuffs is done by the first one, and all the supernatural mumbo-jumbo gone (not completely, but it put in bare minimum). Thief II doesn’t have to suffer with all of these, it has a better pacing, more focused, more intricate dystopian-thriller story, set in an even more well realized steampunk setting. From a “modest” manor to a high security, 6 story towers, from stealing lowly goods to ancient mask, Thief has a unique storytelling, we all are as clueless as Garrett is,  all the story elements dropped in the perfect time and place. Take example for Karass, the antagonist, the common people only know him as “The guy who leads The Mechanists Order”, and so does Garrett, and us, the player view him, and he becomes a more threatening figure, and that’s through texts and overall environmental storytelling only. Stealth At It’s Purest Form While Thief Gold is a thieving game turned-supernatural stealth-semi-platformer halfway, The Metal Age is a “thieving simulator” all the way to  the end. Thief II is simply a much more refined version of Thief I, minus the annoying zombies, and maze-like location, my biggest gripe with Thief I. Improved graphic, making a more beautiful contrast between light and dark, and improved sound design. All thanks to  the amazing “Dark Engine”, an engine designed for Thief, and Thief alone, and yes, I know System Shock 2 use this engine too, but Dark Engine truly shows it’s technical prowess here. It has a unique aesthetic and probably the best “built-in” directional sound design ever. Even until now, I can’t think of any game that has a directional sound so spot on even without the help of a software and hardware  Thief is a stealth game at  it’s purest, most immersive form. Your ear, eyes, patience, and common sense is your greatest strength. Thief is a slow, I mean, really slow stealth game, especially on expert where you can’t kill any humans. Stay in the shadow, lean on every corner, creep your way around, and be patient and spatially aware, because once you’re caught, well, you're one dead thief, especially if you play on expertThe interface is minimalistic, there’s your health, your light gem, and inventory. No mini map and quest markers.  That help a lot with the immersion, you are lead to appreciate and respect the surrounding area, the unique art style and layout in each level, heightened your spatial awareness.There's one flaw in this game and that's the AI, they are... inconsistent. Ranging from nearly blind/deaf (or both), to superhuman sense. You might think the AI gets smarter every time you advance to the next level, well.. to an extent yes, but for the most part, it's "unpredictable". The Art of Level Verticality Two defining characteristic of Thief, that Thief II managed to improved, as I said earlier are the sound design and level design. I won’t delve deeper into sound design, because there’s not much to write about. It’s simply amazing, spot on, and overall has a defining "exaggerated" sound design. Let’s focus on level design for now. It’s FANTASTIC, it’s huge, titanic huge, believable, follows architectural logic, and has an "oppressive" atmosphere throughout that fit with the theme very well. Unlike the second half of Thief Gold, when the level goes total mind♥♥♥♥, in a good way, mostly. In term of level scenery, Thief Gold has more variation, from tomb, prison, cathedral, ruins, and mansions. Thief II levels are all worldly architecture. Only one level that goes to Thief Gold territory and that happens to be my least favorite level. As I said, it’s huge, more complex, but logical complex, that what makes Thief II a more fun experience than Gold. It’s harder to get lost, even if I do it’s easy to get back on track, making the exploration much more enjoyable. The level verticality is simply astounding, so many paths, some is more obvious than others, some require keen eyes and careful exploration, some requires you to hear conversations and reading notes. It’s so rewarding every time you enter a room, and realize there are 3 or more ways to get in / across. There is a vent that connects that room to the basement, the celling that connects to the attic, there’s always the so obvious ground hallway, or you can move through the interconnected rooms and picking up loots and notes, and oh! There’s a secret passage if you put out that fire, saves my time from creeping out this place!  Every route is fun to take on, making every level looks larger than it is. Besides there’s no better feeling when stumble across some loots on the way.  Less Is More One major flaw in the gaming industry trend nowadays is the fact that a lot of today’s games forget the phrase “Less is more”, the removal of an element hold the same importance, or even greater importance nowadays, as adding one. They take a shotgun approach, throwing everything that looks cool hoping it will sticks. It’s not necessarily bad, but with that design philosophy in mind, a game will become a “Jack of all trades, master of none” and directionless. That’s a plague that need to put in moderation.Thief in the other hand, is already set out to be a hardcore stealth game from the very start. It’s simple and humble in presentation, and that’s what makes it works in perfect harmony.  With a “realistic stealth/thieving game” in mind, Looking Glass can focus on what’s important on  a stealth game. The combat is terrible, the gadgets are mostly stealth oriented, you are “forced” to do the stealthy way, but it’s fine, it’s a stealth game after all. It’s not about playstyles in Thief, it’s about the route you take and they deliver. Through The Looking Glass If I have to pick what’s the most underrated game developer for me, it’ll be a tie between Looking Glass and Black Isle. Though I might choose Looking Glass, because Thief, System Shock, and Ultima Underworld are less known than Black Isle’s Fallout series alone. Without them, there’ll be no Ion Storm (Deus Ex), Irrational (BioShock), and Arkane (Dishonored), it’s no coincidence that all of them are such  a hit. So short lived yet so influential, A timeless stealth game Thief II Is. A more than worthy successor of an already near-flawless game, and a perfect game to end an era.This game definitely deserve the "Test of Time" award

												Thief 2: The Metal Age, developped by (the long since defunct) Looking Glass Studios, is the direct sequel to 1998's Thief:The Dark Project. To summarize, you play as master thief Garret (voiced by the great Stephen Russel) who is trying to unravel The City's new religious order, The Mechanists (the replacement of the first game's Hammerites, who believed in the Creator and that industrial construction was the way to keep evil influences, such as the Trickster (a Pan-esque God who worships chaos and nature) at bay. If you don't understand you should check out the first game, it's great!) and their leader, Father Karras, the likes of which are inventing new mechanical innovations in security and industry (robot guards, cameras,etc). The core stealth gameplay is still here from Thief 1, with the ability to deal with guards either lethally or nonlethally (avoiding or blackjacking them) and either playstyles are sufficiently suitable for every mission. This is primarily because the level design in Thief 2 (like its predecessor) contains many hidden paths and secrets to find and explore to deal with mission objectives and secure the most amount of loot possible. Also with new items such as invisibility potions and old ones such as noisemaker arrows (used to distract guards and clear paths), as previously stated, both playstyles are equally supported in the game. The stealth mechanics are still as great as the first game, with the "light gem" still in effect( flashing white if you are visible; dark if you are not), the ability to lean around corners to see guards/ cameras/etc. and the aforementioned items to facilitate being stealthy. One improvement I loved from Thief 2 is the change of setting for the missions, from looting ancient crypts and supernatural dimensions( still awesome but not very thief-like) to looting actual mansions and houses (especially the amount of loot in every level, with multiple areas to scour and explore). And whilst these houses and mansions may not look too good, i feel the art style has a certain charm to it.  Another reason why i enjoy this game? Its story and atmosphere, Garret's tale and The City's backstory is thoroughly established in the pre mission cutscenes and books and texts found throughout levels. And the game's soundtrack is simply amazing, with chilling sweeping synths and general dark tones, the game's soundtrack gives the player a sense of always being watched, of potentially being hunted down, which gives the game's world such a distinctive feeling of ambience and general eerieness. But these are just my thoughts so feel free to check this amazing game out if you'd like, but I'd recommend checking out the first game beforehand, then diving into The Metal Age's world.

												Thief 2, The Metal Age was a game that I very much enjoyed playing, and although it’s quite old, I still think it holds up very well. In Thief 2, you play as Garrett, a master thief who must overcome recent trouble involving a corrupt Sheriff who has cracked down on crime, and who seems to have a personal grudge against Garrett. Throughout the game, you must sneak around in various missions and locations, all while uncovering a potentially much larger problem that goes beyond Garrett himself. In terms of gameplay, it plays similar to the first Thief game. You sneak around, completing various objectives, all while trying to remain unnoticed. While combat is an option, Garrett is rather unequipped when it comes to fighting enemies, and stands little chance against more than one foe at a time. Stealth is by far the best option, and Thief 2 still holds up as one of the best stealth games i’ve played. Guards have long, unpredictable patrols they take, meaning they don’t simply walk from one end of the room to the other making them easy targets, which keeps the game tense and forces the player to always be on their toes in case a guard shows up unexpectedly. Guards are always alert, and will investigate a noise they hear. If they catch a glimpse of you, they may decide to look around, forcing the player to keep moving so that they aren’t found. Garrett’s main means of hiding is darkness. By hiding in the shadows, guards won’t be able to spot the player, allowing them to sneak around unnoticed. The mechanic of hiding in darkness and being exposed in the light works excellently in the game, and it was quite revolutionary for its time. Another interesting mechanic is how not all floors produce the same amount of noise when stepped on. Things like carpet and grass will produce little noise, while marble floors will produce more noise, potentially bringing guards over as well. As you progress through the game and begin stealing from richer people, more marble flooring will be found and more electric lights will be used, meaning it will get harder to keep quiet and stay in the dark. The level design is some of the best i’ve seen, even an improvement on the excellent design of the first game. Levels are non-linear, large, and open, and can have many different sections, each with their own ways to sneak around undetected. The levels are also very varied. Some you may find yourself in a huge mansion, some in the streets of the city, and in many other locations as well. Garrett will have a large array of tools at his disposal to help him through the levels, including many different types of arrows such as water and vine arrows that will help in certain scenarios. Thief 2 also wisely gets rid of the more paranormal settings and enemies that were common in the first game and replaces them with more stealth focused ones. In the first Thief, many of the levels revolved around ruins and caves filled with enemies such as zombies. These levels didn’t offer much in terms of stealth, and for the most part involved simply running right by the enemies while avoiding their attacks. Enemies such as zombies are rarely seen in Thief 2, and luckily don’t break the flow of the stealth gameplay. Thief 2 does use new enemies in the form of robots, but luckily they can be snuck around, making them similar to guards. They also offer a good challenge, because they cannot be knocked out, and throughout playing the game I never once destroyed one. I don’t even know if it was possible to destroy one in the game at all.The game and the people in it also have a lot of charm. Garrett isn’t some lifeless protagonist; he’s a man who can take a moment seriously, but isn’t afraid to make a few cynical remarks about the people he’s stealing from. He isn’t some special hero who people shower with praise, he’s just a guy trying to make enough money from stealing to pay his rent. The guards in the game also have excellent, sometimes quite funny dialogue, and the drunken tone of their voice is a great way to get across their character. The story itself is also very good, and is often told in a non-direct fashion, meaning the player will learn more about the story and world by reading notes left on people's desks, listening to guards talking to each other, as well as other ways. This also gives players more of a reason to look around and explore the environments. While the story itself may seem simple at first, it slowly builds up and becomes something more. It’s rarely a flashy story, but it’s subtle, as well as intriguing and interesting at the same time.I can only really think of two complaints about the game, and they're both pretty minor. First, climbing in the game can be a bit difficult, and if you miss the ledge your trying to grab, the character may jump by accident and alert guards to your location. Second, it seems a bit unfair that taking one step on a marble floor brings every guard in the nearby area to your location, especially when guards are already walking over marble floors without anyone caring. Still, these are only small complaints and they didn't get in the way of my enjoyment of the game.Overall, Thief 2 offers a great improvement over an already great game. It’s one of the best stealth games around, and it has gameplay that still holds up today. The graphics will seem quite dated by today's standards, but if you’re able to get around that, it shouldn’t hinder your enjoyment. One of my favorite games.

												When Thief II released, I had probably already spent over 300 hours (re)playing Thief: The Dark Project and Thief: Gold. Shortly after its release, I rebuilt my PC and dove in. The graphics were much improved from the first games, and the story was even better. The missions were even more expansive this time, and replaying the game always led to finding something new. What made this game even more brilliant, was the opening of the Dark Engine to the users who wanted to mod/level build. Looking Glass Studios closed shortly after the release of Thief II and the sequel wasn't produced until 2004. In that period of downtime, hundreds of new, fan-made, missions were created and distributed in online communities like the Circle of Stone and Shadow. Some were better than others. And just a few may have been better than the game itself. In fact, one of the fan missions was so good, the developer was hired by Eidos to work on Thief III. Moreover, some fan mission developers ended up joining forces to release their own, unofficial sequel named Thief2x. The game itself had its own replay value, but the fans who made these missions and mods increased the value tenfold. Thief II is a must play. I'd definitely recommend playing Thief: The Dark Project or Thief: Gold first. When you're done, it's worth doing the investigation to find these fan-made missions and play them too.

												I've been a Thief fan since The Dark Project came out, first introducing "first-person sneakers". I just deided to play Thief 2 again after buying it on Steam. WOW is it different than "THIEF" (the newest one, not part of the original trilogy). It's in a league of its own. Strategy, timing, and pure stealth are key in the Thief trilogy. This was also true in the first one, Thief: The Dark Project. When you're getting your bearings and trying to find a safe time to move (which is a constant throughout the game), listening is key. If you have a busy or otherwise noisy household, you're gonna have a hard time playing this game. It is absolutely reliant upon being able to listen closely to the movements of nearby NPCs, and sometimes the spoken hints as you're listening to their conversations.To make Thief 2 even better, it not only has zombies sometimes like Thief 1, but it also has "metal beasts" -- creations of the Mechanists (a splinter of the Hammerite cult), which are creepy in their own way, but also very hard to kill if you find yourself in that position.I miss games back in the day. In the bank level, the first time I played it, it took me just over 4 hours to beat. That's just one of many levels. What made so many older games awesome was that some games had absolutely gargantuan levels, and in the Thief trilogy they had a dozen ways of being completed, increasing replayability, whereas games today tend to be so linear, with the exception of a rare few.Enjoy it!

												Thief 2: The Metal Age is a direct sequel to the Thief: The Dark Project, this one released in 2000 and made by Looking Glass. At the core it uses same mechanics and even same techonology of engine as the original, so some might think of it as expansion pack. Yet it's upper level of design is different, being designed like a proper stealth game and having more steampunk setting.Also, yea, you probably heard that this version doesn't have credits music. It's not a false statement, but it's not suppose to have one to begin with. It's just that localizator of German version decided to add some song from some German band. Doesn't sound Thief-like at all.Technically, it's released as-is and thus has some problems. Like, it doesn't support widescreen resolution or anything more than 800x600.I think that just like with Thief 1 on Steam, to see cutscenes you have to run .exe file with admin rights. But I think it already does it?I also noticed that the gamma slider doesn't work either. And in this one I felt that the game is way too dark by default. Or maybe Thief 1 is the one which is too bright. Not sure.Also, yea, enable fogging in options, it's art-improving graphic option, not "hide things if far away".Then again, you probably should use one of a community patches. Not sure how much do they change, I was there for Vanilla experience, but people love those, so.Plot once again follows our cynical thief by the name of Garrett in the mysterious City. In the first game he had to destroy the Trickster, god of Pagans house of nature, who wished to destroy everything man-build. This heroic deed shifted the balance of powers toward the path of progress, to a dawn of the twisted Metal Age. Pure fantasy elements and monsters are almost not seen, The City is being cleaned by the City Watch and a new Mechanists sect emerges out of Hammerite house to lead the age.And yea, the story continues, as everything here shifts to steampunk and Victorian setting. And Thief is focusing more on just being a thief, rather than adventurer. No more adventure, you now have big houses and mansion to rob and even your maps are always accurate and provide good description to let you. It even feels less linear due to this, albeit actual levels are less dragged due to less maze-like qualities and less of fetching and puzzles. But hey, this is what people expect Thief to be.And it futher embraces the fact that it's more focused on stealth. You got new tools of trade, like Invinsibility potions, slow-fall one. There is a scouting orb that you can throw anytime and see from it's point of view, which I always forget to use even though AI never notices this so there is no good reason not to. Remember kids - don't be like me, that's not smart choice.You can now lean into door to eaversdrop. Guards pretty much always mumble something to themselves, futher giving you audio hints. Some rare guards even wear special helmets that you can't blackjack them. Althrough they are so rare that I don't remember any such encounter. There are even occasional patrol that have more than one person.And it's a Metal Age that we are talking about, with Mechanists bringing new toys to watch out. There are surveliance camera, security systems and robots, which can be divided into huge dangerous robot that can't hear and small robot that can only warn others, but only after first hearing you, activating their vision and seeing you. All mixed with humans, giving more stealth-focused variety instead of monsters. All while you are cracking the bank level with it's ceramic tiles and three floors of complexity.Albeit, it does mean that it lost some of the charm. There isn't much of wonderful immersive mystery that made me fall in love for Thief. That, and I am not fan of this theme, it's just feels too Victorian. It mostly has to do that it actually lost some gameplay variety. There is only so much mansion that you can crack at before it gets a bit old. Which isn't to say that there is no rare mission which goes out of this style. And it also varies the stealth objective that you have, even having this single awesome police station mission where you actually supposed to ghost due to knockouts limit. And it has this awesome mission where you travel on rooftops of a city.But I still can't help but to feel monotomy setting after the half of a game. After all, it still ends up too much with you blackjacking everybody you come across. Or maybe it's because of the plot. It starts nicely, with some conspiracy going on, but soon it's all same grey Mechanics, Mechanics, Mechanics, who lack some charm. Even though their leader is kinda awesome and robot carry it along, but the environment gets you after a while.That, and I am still dissapoint that the plot didn't explore relationship between Hammerites and Mechanics. At least I never seen any actual conflict. Kinda hoped to see the clash of ideals ever since I overheard one of the very rare Hammerites complained in the second level. But oh well.That, and in the last one third of a game it simply farts out. I don't know, it feels like the quality and excitement suddenly drops. Then again, Looking Glass studios was in deep financial trouble and was rushing out, I bet this is the impact to it. The Kidnap level is both boring looking and boring to play, in a cave with more mechanists, where you run all over the place to find the needed NPC. Not to mentioning that I had sudden framedrop because of some trouble with AI pathfinding, until I found the guard who was hogging game up.Then you have two levels in a row that take place in same mansion, in both cased you enter it and exit in. The thing is that the first level of it feels like an earlier development version of the level, while the second time around it doesn't differenate enough to hold interest. Like plot-wise you sneak in to find a secret stairway toward the third floor so you knew where it is to snack masks on next day. After that you are supposed to leave yet you can venture futher into the third floor where you find many glitchy things, with flying decorations, misaligned models and you can even steal the already-present masks, but no one will care. As if you aren't supposed to be there.Final level isn't bad though, at least on second try when I learned how to exploit big robots into blowing up themselves. And when I knew to take it slowly. Kinda like a little nightmare of steel, albeit I can see how some may decide that it goes too long, as well as being a challenge course. It's actually is quite awesome. But then the ending feels dissapointnig. It leaves you with no satisfication of victory and doesn't hype you up for next title. Just ends immeditly, with no music. Unlike the perfect Thief 1 ending.But hey, I don't think that the main point of the games lies in ending. I would say that the Thief 2 is more than worth beating, even if it leaves you a bit sour. It's a Thief game, the one with complex levels, no hand-holding and more focus on stealth. And even though stealth core gameplay is still a bit on simple side, knocking everybody out, despite having excellent audio design that futhers gameplay, it's still a greatly enjoyable game.

												I didn't play the Thief games upon their initial release and so am not reviewing this through the rose-tinted glasses of nostalgia. But I can safely say that these games honestly do still hold up today.Pros:- Light/Dark system is a great mechanic and leads to the player paying more attention to their environment.- Static map, some areas are missing and without an all encompassing minimap you are forced to be more cautious, unsure of what lies around each corner and this adds to the game's  tense atmosphere. - Your footsteps become louder when walking on harder floors such as marble, adds depth and makes you more observant of your surroundings.- No zombies or supernatural elements (preference).- Excellent level design, navigating is not a problem despite not having a full map or quest markers. This is because the levels are designed logically (as though they were not designed just for a game but to serve the purpose of the building e.g a mansion)  and loot is distibuted accordingly, e.g you can safely assume that there will be little to no loot in the servants quarters, but there will more than certainly be something valuable in the nobles quarters.- Tells the story through level design and gameplay instead of directly through a cutscene or text.- You can't choose to go in all guns blazing, you die quickly (2 sword hits) and thus feel more vunerable and this creates tension. You aren't invincible, their is no second option to just fight your way in. Only through the patience and intelligence of the player can Garrett succeed, as you play you become a better thief- not through "levelling up"- you are never given any notification of your progress by the game (this is a good thing), Garrett stays his same vunerable self throughout the whole game, but you the player learn how to handle yourself: which areas are low/high risk, when to blackjack guards, where to hide etc ... This is extremely rewarding as by the end of the game you (the player) have gone from an amateur burglar to a masterthief, this progression of the player instead of the character is extremely rewarding and makes you feel like you are truly getting more skillful- this progression is expressed not through a number or a level and Garrett doesn't become more powerful as you play, your growth is shown in the way you play the game.- Amazing soundtrack.Cons:- May be too dark and hard too see for some.- Not the greatest voice acting.- Graphics whilst not awful do not compare with those of newer titles.You owe it to yourself to experience this masterpiece.

												Next in line in the Thief series, here I am. I have never played any of the games of Thief, though I have always wanted to. I just finished the first game and wrote a review for it, and now have finished the second. The very first Thief disappointed me very much, but that was all due to the level design, which ruined the whole experience for me. However, I was still greatly interested in the world's atmosphere and story, so I was hopeful with this game and came in with a neutral outlook.Thief II greatly increased my expectations through the first two-thirds of the game, but quickly disappointed me again with the last 5 missions and the ending. Firstly, just to brush through everything else, as I don't need to say much more here than I did with the first Thief:+ The story and the atmosphere given by it is just as engaging.+ The graphics were better than the first game's, and the world mostly looked like it was put together better in each level. The cinematics were pretty much the same in style, however.+ Garrett is still just as likable of a character!+ The sound effects are mostly similar, and the voice acting is still well done, except for Karras, which I will go into more detail later.+ The gameplay mechanics are mostly the same as well, not too much new, though I enjoyed things like the robotic cameras you can throw.In the end, most of the above is rather the same, though slightly improved in one way or another. Nothing too drastically new in those areas... but the level design, now that was so much better! Based on the first two-thirds of the game, I have to say that the levels were (mostly) great, so much better than 90% of the levels in the first game.The first level was an interesting start, especially neat for clearing a path for an NPC. The second, however, was pretty bad and generic again, scaring me that the game would be the same. The storage area was nothing special, and the design of having to repeatedly go to the office, punch in a code, and go back out so many times was just bad.But afterwards, the game picked back up very well. I liked every mission up to and including Life of the Party, though the Eavesdropping/Bank missions were nothing too special. Ambush was actually a very good mission for me. I enjoyed running throughout the city, trying to weave my own path back to my place, creeping around. Life of the Party was my other favorite mission, sneaking around on the rooftops being my favorite part. Before that, Trail of Blood was interesting as well, mostly in the environment and the ghosts you kept encountering.None of those levels were really that confusing as in the first game either. They were no longer wide open, empty areas. Instead, you could get a better grasp on where you were for the most part, and I could always keep track of what I was doing, never getting bored.Then came the last third of the game, back to terrible. From the first Cavador mission forward, I didn't enjoy the environments anymore, nor did the levels keep me entertained. Even worse, the Casing the Joint mission was a generic build for the most part. I mean, I was interested with the secret paths throughout the place at first, but to be honest, they wore out pretty quickly, as the mission was such a pain of trial-and-error, more so than any other mission. Then the immediately next mission throws you back into the same exact mansion with basically no difference! What a pain, and what a terrible design decision.And for the finale, Soulforge wasn't linear like in the original game, but it wasn't interesting either. The first room you start in looked cool, then everything else was just generic looking and full of robots. I understand that it fits the story (the Metal Age!) but it didn't make me want to keep going. And that ending cinematic, wow! The ending of the first game wasn't the greatest, but still much better than this one. It seems that Looking Glass really didn't know how to end games, between System Shock 2 and these two Thief games.As a side note, mentioned above, Karras had the worst voice of the game. So terrible. He sounded like he just had this nasal jelly mass stuck in his throat. There is some weird, annoying cartoon character that it reminded me of, but I can't remember for the life of me, at the moment. I know that Stephen Russell did the voice and he also does many others, included Garrett's! But Karras is so different, and literally I had to mute my sound any time his voice was prominent throughout the game. I can't really say there have been many voices that have caused me to do that, and it was only slightly worse that all of the robots spout his voice too.In the end, I was really impressed with about half of the game, neutral for a little piece, and then very disappointed with the last third. Do I recommend that people play the game? Sure. I enjoyed it for a good while, much more than I did the first game. I will never play the first game again, whereas I might play some of the missions here again.Now, I am onto the third game, Deadly Shadows. Let's see how it goes!

												Next in line in the Thief series, here I am. I have never played any of the games of Thief, though I have always wanted to. I just finished the first game and wrote a review for it, and now have finished the second. The very first Thief disappointed me very much, but that was all due to the level design, which ruined the whole experience for me. However, I was still greatly interested in the world's atmosphere and story, so I was hopeful with this game and came in with a neutral outlook.Thief II greatly increased my expectations through the first two-thirds of the game, but quickly disappointed me again with the last 5 missions and the ending. Firstly, just to brush through everything else, as I don't need to say much more here than I did with the first Thief:+ The story and the atmosphere given by it is just as engaging.+ The graphics were better than the first game's, and the world mostly looked like it was put together better in each level. The cinematics were pretty much the same in style, however.+ Garrett is still just as likable of a character!+ The sound effects are mostly similar, and the voice acting is still well done, except for Karras, which I will go into more detail later.+ The gameplay mechanics are mostly the same as well, not too much new, though I enjoyed things like the robotic cameras you can throw.In the end, most of the above is rather the same, though slightly improved in one way or another. Nothing too drastically new in those areas... but the level design, now that was so much better! Based on the first two-thirds of the game, I have to say that the levels were (mostly) great, so much better than 90% of the levels in the first game.The first level was an interesting start, especially neat for clearing a path for an NPC. The second, however, was pretty bad and generic again, scaring me that the game would be the same. The storage area was nothing special, and the design of having to repeatedly go to the office, punch in a code, and go back out so many times was just bad.But afterwards, the game picked back up very well. I liked every mission up to and including Life of the Party, though the Eavesdropping/Bank missions were nothing too special. Ambush was actually a very good mission for me. I enjoyed running throughout the city, trying to weave my own path back to my place, creeping around. Life of the Party was my other favorite mission, sneaking around on the rooftops being my favorite part. Before that, Trail of Blood was interesting as well, mostly in the environment and the ghosts you kept encountering.None of those levels were really that confusing as in the first game either. They were no longer wide open, empty areas. Instead, you could get a better grasp on where you were for the most part, and I could always keep track of what I was doing, never getting bored.Then came the last third of the game, back to terrible. From the first Cavador mission forward, I didn't enjoy the environments anymore, nor did the levels keep me entertained. Even worse, the Casing the Joint mission was a generic build for the most part. I mean, I was interested with the secret paths throughout the place at first, but to be honest, they wore out pretty quickly, as the mission was such a pain of trial-and-error, more so than any other mission. Then the immediately next mission throws you back into the same exact mansion with basically no difference! What a pain, and what a terrible design decision.And for the finale, Soulforge wasn't linear like in the original game, but it wasn't interesting either. The first room you start in looked cool, then everything else was just generic looking and full of robots. I understand that it fits the story (the Metal Age!) but it didn't make me want to keep going. And that ending cinematic, wow! The ending of the first game wasn't the greatest, but still much better than this one. It seems that Looking Glass really didn't know how to end games, between System Shock 2 and these two Thief games.As a side note, mentioned above, Karras had the worst voice of the game. So terrible. He sounded like he just had this nasal jelly mass stuck in his throat. There is some weird, annoying cartoon character that it reminded me of, but I can't remember for the life of me, at the moment. I know that Stephen Russell did the voice and he also does many others, included Garrett's! But Karras is so different, and literally I had to mute my sound any time his voice was prominent throughout the game. I can't really say there have been many voices that have caused me to do that, and it was only slightly worse that all of the robots spout his voice too.In the end, I was really impressed with about half of the game, neutral for a little piece, and then very disappointed with the last third. Do I recommend that people play the game? Sure. I enjoyed it for a good while, much more than I did the first game. I will never play the first game again, whereas I might play some of the missions here again.Now, I am onto the third game, Deadly Shadows. Let's see how it goes!

												This is my second review for the second game in this eponymous stealth series, enjoy B's.Pro's: This game, just like its predecessor before it, really makes you feel like a Thief. When all the cylinders in your brain are firing off at perfect formation you will honestly feel like no one can stop you from "borrowing" their precious goods. The game is a direct follow up to The Dark Project (Thief Gold) and continues pretty much right after the first game, give or take a month or two. One thing they really improved upon in this game is the level design. I didn't think they could make it any better but it's even more logical now rather than Maze-like. Thief Gold also had logical level design but some of the levels were more like Mazes than a real tangible place that you could believe existed. In this game it feels more grounded than the first and more tangible, you rob a Bank, Frame a City Watch guard, Tail an informant, Crash a party and rob the denizens of the City, and help a friend rescue his unrequited love. All of those things add up to an experience that permeates into something so immutably real that I almost forgot I was playing a damn game.Another thing that really helps you get immersed is Garrett himself, he now talks and comments on things way more frequently and has more character depth overall. Which in turn makes him even more likeable than he already was. Without spoiling anything there is one part where you break into some ladies home and Garrett just calmly says "Don't mind me ladies, just passing through" it really makes you feel like he is more than just a cypher for the player. Another real huge improvement is the inclusion of proper secrets in every mission. Most missions can have up to 8 or more secrets for you to find and they can be as simple as a short-cut or something really nice like some loot for you to plunder.  Con's: Once again there is not very many faults with this game but if there is one thing I didn't like as much as the first game it is the villain. He has a voice that sounds like a mixture of Cartman and Meatwad. Hard to feel intimidated by someone like that when I have that image in my head. He isn't a terribly written character and I really dig his motives and behaviour I just think a better voice could have gone a long way to make him seem badass. Maybe another complaint I can say is the final 3 missions are kind of "Meh" overall and the ending as a whole isn't as awesome as the first game.  Overall Feelings & Score: I feel like this game is not only just a worthy sequel to the first game but it is also a damn fine game in its own right. I give the game a $ out of *...make up your own mind and decide for yourself if you can enter...The Metal Age. Mind your P's and Q's because your balls, are, about to drop sirs and madams, peace the F out!

												After finishing System Shock 2 in 1999, The geniuses at Looking Glass Studios would set out to create a sequel to their most successful franchise. It would sadly be their last ever game as financial problems would see the studio close 2 months later.Thief 2 is everything you could possibly ask for in a sequel; tighter and much larger level design, deeper exploration of the characters, a tighter and a more coherent atmosphere and an enthralling story of an unlikely alliance solving a twisting and evolving mystery that threatens to destroy The City and beyond.Once again, Garrett is the unlikely hero of the tale. Stealing to survive and slinking through the shadows are a daily fact of life for him; Getting to the truth, whilst stopping to line his pockets along the way.You'll be exploring nobleman's estates, police stations, banks, cathedrals and even The Thieves' Highway. All the while, the atmosphere and storytelling will keep you on your toes and keep your mind sharp. The environments in Thief 2 are much bigger and much more detailed than the first game and gone are the vast majority of undead, haunted crypts and tombs the first game contained. You'll also have some new gear to play with in Thief 2; Slow-fall potions, expensive and rare invisibility potions, flash mines and 'The Eye', which I won't go into much detail about, as well as others.Thief 2 is also more challenging than the first game. Higher difficulty levels will, in some cases, require you to leave very little or, in one case, zero trace of your presence behind in one or two levels. This will require you to think ahead even more about what to expect; a tense but rewarding experience.This game the peak of the Thief series so far, the graphics are much improved over the first game and the story, whilst having a satisfying conclusion, left the door wide open for a Thief 3 that would never arrive from the studio that started it all.So Adiós Looking Glass. You created amazing experiences, stories and gameplay long before it was the norm in gaming as we know it today and even now, studios are still playing catchup to you.The game is very mod friendly. 												Thief II is a steampunk stealth game.It's a Singleplayer only game. Release date: 21.03.2000Graphics:    6/10The graphics are ok for its release date. In comparison to the prequel it's only a slight improvement, but I think they could've made it a little bit better than they actually did. Like the prequel they managed to create an awesome atmosphere with the "poor" graphics and effects. One reason I just gave 6/10 is that most of the game looks 1:1 exactly the same likeThief Gold.Sound:     6/10The sounds are quite good and the voice actors are doing a great job. Some sounds are really annoying (robots for example). Like in Thief Gold there is nearly no music. I know it's not necessary, but I still miss it.Level design:     7/10The level design is just as good as in the prequel. You can search for secrets and have more than one way to reach your goal. The atmosphere is fitting and the levels are well structured.Except for one level, namely the last one. The last level is so frustrating. If you want to sneak the whole way through then you get detected the slow way. If you want to rush through you get detected fast. That is the only difference and the reason why I skipped the last level. And this last level degrades the Level design by 2 points: 9/10 => 7/10.Gameplay/Handling/Equipment:     8/10The good points: Like in the prequel you have a really nice arsenal for a thief. Plenty of arrowtypes, the flashbomb for your escape and so on. You still must get used to the controls but when you know how to play it you will like it. The playstyle remains pretty much like it was in the prequel. You sneak around, steal stuff, knock out enemies, etc..The bad point: No improvements at all.Enemies/AI:     6/10Well the guards search for you if you are too loud and act really authentic. But robots act totally random and I don't get the point why they made them so annoying. Sure it's no problem to disable them but still I don't like the idea of them. They didn't improve the AI from Thief Gold to Thief 2 so I just give 6/10.Story:     4/10Maybe it's just me but I don't like the story. It's boring and I miss the "magical" part of it. The target is a guy who wants to kill people with poison and created robots to protect himself. I don't even know how to make it sound better.Critic summary:     6,2/10Personal fun rating:     7/10     [good game]All in all a good game, but the developers didn't make real improvements. I recommend the game if you played Thief Gold, otherwise I don't. Since the game isn't very expensive: Give it a try.

												How does one rave about one of their all time favorite games without sounding like a raving lunatic?Look, there are 4 (sorta) Thief games.  If each of them gets 10 points (so a total of 40) and you break it up here's the ranking:Theif II: The Metal Age 50/10Thief: The Dark Project (Gold) 10/10Thief: Deadly Shadows 5/10Thief -25/10But that includes 3 stories for another time.I do have to mention Dark Project/Gold briefly since Thief II would not exist without it.  It really is a fine game in its own right, the best Stealth Game up to that point.  However, it still relies too much on combat (and those damnable undead). The story, however, is worth it.  Which leads to Thief II -- apparently Looking Glass Studios realized that the combat was the least favorite aspect of the game and made it so you can avoid it entirely in Thief II (if you choose).  You may get seen and want to fight your way out (or have to I suppose) and you are not entirely without resources.  However, you CAN get through it without ever swinging your blade.  That, in conjunction with the story, propelled Theif II to the top of the stealth charts for me.Do not look for visuals that have withstood the test of time.  They are dated, but they are sufficient if you aren't a snob, and the aesthetic works perfectly.  Do not look for this if you want to run and gun through levels putting arrows into the eye sockets of every guard you see while simultaneously slicing and dicing others who happen to get to close.DO look for an amazing stealth game with a solid story that builds from at first trying to scratch out a living to getting embroiled in events beyond your control.  DO look for secret rooms, safes, stashed of loot.  DO be patient and learn the guard's patterns.  But mostly -- DO PICK UP Thief II: The Metal Age (especially during this stealth game sale!).One last thing -- DO NOT pick up Thief (the reboot) as it has in common with the true Thief games only the title and the name of the protagonist.  They are as different as having a fire and being on fire.

												The graphics for this game may not be as spectacular compared to other stealth games like Metal Gear Solid but the gameplay more than makes up for that.Taking place in a Victorian steam punk era with limited amounts of magic, you have to rely on quick wit and your arsenal to advance in the game.  Two guards block a doorway you need to enter through.  You could carefully sneak through the dark and bypass them, you could use an arrow to make a sound, drawing them away, or find a hidden passage in the wall to sneak behind them.  This is what makes the game so great, you have options you can use and not keep things so linear.The difficulty also makes the game great.  There is no indicater of any kind to tell you there is a guard on the other side of the wall.  You have to use your ears to listen to footsteps, occasionally whistling, and eyes to see if that guard is carrying a key to unlock a door with.One of the cons I can say about the game is the controls at times can be a little frustrating to deal with.  Sometimes you want to climb up a short wall, quietly, only to have Garrett not only miss grabbing the wall, he may make some noise too, alerting the guards.  I had a similar problem with ladders, with him not dismounting from the well.The cut scenes are kept short and in between each mission.  Most of the story is told from reading parchments, books, and listening to game characters talk amongst themselves.If you're looking for a stealth game that IS superior to most other stealth games, like Metal Gear, I would highly recommend this game ot

												Thief 2: TMA is everything a sequel should be, and more! Though  it doesn't have the same 'horror' element that the first game had, it's still very atmospheric with an incredible ambience that will suck you in to its dark, treacherous world and it won't let go until Karras closes the doors to Soulforge, forever sealing his fate! (yeah, more on Soulforge later).All of the original Thief gameplay mechanics are still in place w/ added features: the stealth is in full effect with deeply complex missions and large maps that allow for multiple routes to completing objectives, all the sexy arrow types you loved from the first game are back (now with vine arrows), all of your original gadgets are back (now with scouting orbs, and in rare cases explosive devices), there are new enemy types (most notably female soldiers) and of course a new antagonist (alas, Constantine is no more, but Karras is easily just as much of a♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥as he was, so it's cool, and there's even a ghost pirate at one point if you can find him and his glorious pirate booty....um....let me rephrase that, I mean his treasure).  Oh, and I almost forgot one of the coolest upgrades, the cinematics between missions (some play out like storyboard drawings but others are actual cinematics and there's sorta one when you die too, but obviously that's not as cool as the others).Now back to the final mission, Sabotage at Soulforge, Karras' stronhold, his HQ, the locus of his nefarious activities, yeah you get the point.  Being a final mission you'd expect some level of challenge and complexity and Soulforge certainly doesn't disappoint. But seriously, this mission for me was so vast and complex that I spent nearly a quarter of my total game time wandering its darkened corridors with like negative 5 hitpoints at some points, all while trying to figure out where I should go next and how not to get killed by Karras' mechanoid creations. After finally beating this mission, I almost felt like I couldn't recall an earlier point in the game but Soulforge.  It was as though the entire game took place in this one hub-like area.  Mentally, I was nearly defeated by this final quest but I persevered in the end and so Karras can suck it!If you like Thief you'll love this one just as much, if not more so.  Get it on sale when you can but as far as classics go, it's a must own even if you have to pay the full price and there is so much depth and challenge that you'll be glad you made the purchase in the end.

												I left it feeling ... blasé? I would still recommend several of the missions. Shipping and Recieving, Framed, Trace the Courier, and Trail of Blood I remember fondly. Life of the Party, Masks, and Running Interference were good as well, but I remember my frustration first and their positive traits second. When I think of Thief:TMA, I think of being aggravated that I can't move around. This was something that happened in Thief:TDP, but in that game, it wasn't a problem. Not only were there breathers were I could sprint across open grass, or swim in relative safety, but also I was immersed and excited by the locations and the many many hidden secrets and background I was constantly happening across.     "I wandered around lost and unsure a lot, but there was nothing that was unenjoyable about doing that. The game encourages you to do so, and there is a lot to discover (and steal) while you unlock the greater picture of the mission. I played slowly and patiently, but I missed a lot of content and could easily play it again for a new experience." I don't feel the same way about TMA. There are a lot of reasons for that.I don't like metal floors constantly placing me in danger of being heard. I don't like more guards and cameras everywhere. I don't like metal and concrete factories as settings to explore. I don't like the notes and conversations by normal goons about normal grounded things. I don't like having no "free range" areas. I don't remember enjoying the stories or notes and background. I don't remember finding many hidden objects or spots I didn't expect to be able to access. It all feels a lot more empty and a lot more tedious. But compared against other games? Well, it's old, ugly, clunky and slow paced. The controls are broken and awkward. I remember being frustrated more than anything else. Stilllll.....In the end, I would recommend it. For one, I might have simply been tired of this type gameplay by the time I finished it. I know the thrilling feeling of mastery from T:TDP would come from this game's mechanics as well. It is a well balanced game with a story and setting that is unique and palpable. There are many routes, tactics, and styles of facing obstacles. And, in the end, there are few things better than being Garrett in a dark corner of a huge complex; rifling through every corner, filling my pockets full of gold, and my head full of knowledge that is very much not supposed to belong to me.

												If you thought Thief Gold was pretty good, then you'll think Thief II is incredible.The Metal Age is stealth game perfection. Even though a lot of the stealth mechanics don't make much sense, such as a guard not being able to see you should you be standing inches away from them if you're in a dark spot of a brightly lit room, everything about this game is FUN. You'll spend about 40-60 minutes in each level, and that's if you're ignoring picking up all of the loot that's scattered around.The story, in comparison to the original Thief, is very well written and intriguing. The plot in the original had you fighting zombies and tomb raiding, while in this game, the focus is on the transition from a dark ages fantasy game to "The Metal Age". You don't feel so much like a spelunking knight with a sword and bow and arrow, but an actual thief, taking on bank heists and even sneaking through a medieval police station and stealing from the evidence vault. The screenshots displayed on the Store Page really don't do the game justice. For a game from 2000 the graphics have aged tremendously, and the lighting and texture work look fantastic to this day. My favorite level is the bank, just because of how spectacular the green tiled floors, wooden walkways, and red carpeted offices look. Not only do the levels look incredible, but they have some pretty great layouts and the level design is ingenious, inventive and sprawling. After replaying the bank mission so many times I've found six different ways to enter the building, and there are so many different routes you can take to get to the vault without being spotted it's insane. From crawling through a vent and dropping down into the offices adjacent to the vault room, shutting down the mechanical faces (which act as cameras hanging from the ceiling and spinning around trying to spot you) by flipping a switch on the third floor and going through the teller gates, or going through the lions den and using a rope arrow attached to the ceiling to cross the Guard's Room and into the backdoor of the vault room. I also love that each section of the immensely huge levels has a little nugget of dialogue to be heard that are entertaining to listen to and informative. The voice acting isn't great, but I always ended up quicksaving each time I heard a guard speaking with another guard so I could hear the full thing and then quickload so I didn't lose any time. What is really well done however is Garret talking to himself, usually stating the obvious but it helps players stay on track when he explains something to himself the player might not already realize. His little quips and things he says never get old, even after you've played the same level three or four times.In conclusion, this is an outstanding gem of a game that you would be doing yourself a disservice not to play.

												With most things, you expect, as time goes on, that they will improve. Newer cars are better than old, that sort of thing. The stealth genre is the only thing where this doesn\'t seem to be the case. Not to say that there aren\'t good modern day stealth games, of course there are. However, as of right now, none of them have seemed to surpass Thief 2, just offer and equally good experience, despite Thief\'s age. I won\'t go crazy on this review, but here is an example. Hitman is a stealth game of sorts, and as most games do, it discourages you from killing bad guys. The less bodies the better. How does it do this? With points, a negative effect on your over all proformance review, just some numbers on the screen. And thats all fine and dandy. But what about Thief. Thief is entirely organic, as it encourages you to be as stealthy as possible in a totally realistic way, that is much more planned out, while avoiding the whole issue of pulling you out of the experience, reminding you that \"this is just a game\".   If you encounter a guard, you could try to sneak around him. One small mistake could get you killed though, so why not knock him out? You could, but then you have to worry about the body, which if not well hiden enough, could ruin everything. Meanwhile, killing him would be even worse, since that would not only make a body, but also a blood stain, which would require a water arrow to clean. This natural progressing of actions and consequences encourages you to play with as little encounters as possible, instead guiding you to learn to sneak past guards without ever interacting with them in the first place, being the ultimate ninja. But this doesn\'t feel gamey, and doesn\'t feel arbitrary or tedious. This is just one of the many reasons why Thief 2 still stands up as a great stealth game. Buy it, then download tafferpatcher, a program which helps the game run on modern computers. Don\'t worry, it is stupid easy, just download the file, and launch the executable, it takes all of 30 seconds. Plus, there are thousands of fan made levels which the community has made, providing hours of gameplay beyond the base game, so have fun!

												For Thief II, you could mostly just take my Thief Gold review, and then copy/paste all of the pros overtop of all of the cons. Thief II plays mostly the same as Thief Gold. Same graphics, same controls, same first-person view. What they did change, however, makes all the difference.Thief Gold had a number of really fun missions featuring Garrett prowling around a house or opera hall or what-have-you, knocking out guards and discovering secret passages, and those were great. But it spent just as much time knee deep in zombies, apemen, giant bugs, bugmen, ghosts, confusing labyrinths, caves, and situations where you almost HAVE to fight your way out if you're not super-great at the game.For Thief II, the devs looked at what players did and did not enjoy, and they made a game that is better in almost all respects. Save for a single Thief Gold-esque level with some apemen (which is rather forgiving compared to TG, and a fascinating level overall), there are only maybe a couple of any particular monster, and most of them are avoidable. The only new monster type I can recall gave me the biggest (and most enjoyable) fright of anything in either game. The majority of levels take place in sane man-made structures; homes, a bank, a surprisingly modern police station, and a few missions taking place across entire sections of The City. Thus the game now flows better, being less of a half-forced monster combat game, and more about sneaking around, bludgeoning unsuspecting jerks, and looting every last inch of each level.As a result of the titular Metal Age, Thief II also now includes cameras, robots, turrets,  and a selection of new tools at your disposal, such as mines and flares - the latter of which you will absolutely need, as some parts of the game can be far too dark to move around in. It's possible this is an issue on my end, or it may just be part of the game. If it's the game itself, it is one of the very few problems introduced with this installment.Also introduced, however, is a map. Though not always very helpful, it is often an invaluable tool, showing varied degrees of detail depending on the level and keeping track of where you've been and where you currently are.While the final level is complicated and confusing, most of the rest of the game is a blast. One particular element of note is the interesting play on the penultimate levels of Thief Gold. Where in TG, the three levels leading up to the final one were repeat visits to locations you had already been in previous levels, in T2 the fourth-to-last level is ALSO a repeat visit to a location you had already been in Thief Gold, now taken over by the Mechanists. The next-to-last mission is, in fact, the same location as the third-to-last mission, which somehow manages to stay fresh and fun through both levels.In the end, I heavily recommend Thief II if you enjoy stealth games. If you played Thief Gold but only sometimes liked it, I ask that you give Thief II a try instead, as it has ironed out most of the kinks. The only other thing I would like to note is that, like TFix for TG, Thief II is at its best when Tafferpatcher (a fan-made patch which improves resolution, textures, compatibility, etc.) has been applied.Now get thieving, you dirty taffer.

												Thief 2: The Metal Age stands as a perfect example of taking a concept that already exists and improving upon ever facet of it's overall structure and execution.This sequel to the rather popular Thief: The Dark Project takes what made the first game so great,removed all the cave/ruin spelunking,took the idea of being a thief with a task in which there are multiple ways to deal with that task and moved it to the next level in terms of game design.Garret returns for the sequel being the titular thief of the series.Much like the first game's plot,it starts out slow,with Garret carrying out tasks for various people and trying to keep his landlord from banging down his door,all with the use of his variety of ''skills'',this allows for what made the first game great,breaking into places you shouldn't be and taking things you shouldn't own,however,the plot quickly gets to the main agenda and you will begin to carry out jobs that carry more weight than a purse of gold,with implications for the rest of the world and it's fate.Speaking of breaking into places,the level design in this game is among the best I have ever had the joy of experiencing,the now defunct Looking Glass Studios create vast and richly detailed environments for you to explore and plunder,ranging from a large warehouse complex to a collosal tower owned by the fanatical Mechanists,each of these levels were clearly designed with a painstaking amount of effort and it shows with every secret to find and location to explore,never has a game provided the same thrill of being a thief than this game.Despite it's admittedly noticable age,this game still manages to provide a experience that few other games have been able to parallel and it remains a contender for my favourite video game of all time.If you are in anyway a fan of stealth games,you owe it to yourself to experience this masterpiece,be wary though,as you may find your heart has been stolen within the first few levels of loot-filled glory.
