												This is quite possibly the best stealth experience I have ever had. Thief 2: The Metal Age improves upon Thief: The Dark Project (or in our case, Thief: Gold) in every way imaginable. With a greater focus on grand medieval heists and a more focused story along with more polished gameplay this game is by far the best entry in the series.Thief 2 begins some time after the events of Thief: TDP. What makes Thief great in terms of story telling is how fluid and well-paced it is. Starting the game by helping out a friend, then stealing enough loot just to pay your rent until eventually Garrett stumbles on a great threat and then an even greater threat pulling the strings from higher up.Each mission can take you an hour or more to complete. The level design is superb: many rooms boast different types of surfaces which make varying amounts of noise with carpet and grass being the most quiet and tile and metal being the loudest. This game takes advantage of verticality with rope arrows and eventually vine arrows. You can really feel like a Thief when you set up a rope arrows on the roof of a building and lower yourself down to steal a highly valued item and them shimmy back up just before a guard shows up. Levels range from a bank, to a police station to a huge 6 story mansion to an underground base that houses a submarine. There's a lot of variety to be had when it comes to level setting in this game which is greatly appreciated.Gameplay has largely stayed the same but with the addition of a few new gadgets and enemy types. After the events of Thief: TDP Garrett now has a mechanical eye he can make use of, he can use scanning orbs to make sure places are safe before continuing which is a welcome addition. The game also boasts many new enemies such a robots, security cameras and even more varied guard types. For example there are guards wearing thick helmets who cannot be knocked out with the black jack. The best you can do is stun them and when you hit them their helmet will make a loud noise and draw the attention of other guards, luckily these helmet-toting guards are easy to identify. If you disturb guards enough they will be on 24/7 alert. If guards see a pool of blood from you murdering someone they will search the area thoroughly and continue to do so until you are either caught or if you knock them out or kill them. The AI can vary to being absolutely brain-dead (hiding in the shadows and one gets close enough to smell Garrett's breath but doesn't notice him) to being way too sensitive (one step into a dimly lit room and they're already chasing you).Luckily this doesn't happen too often for it to be a serious problem but it does happen.Lastly the sound design is superb. You can hear foot steps of enemies just as well as they can hear yours, you can hear them whistling and talking in a realistic manner. The ambient sounds bring atmosphere to the missions. Whether it be the whistling of the wind, the moans of undead, music at a party or people writing while doing paper work. Thief 2 has amazing sound direction.This game is old and the graphics are dated with a few problems here and there. But the gameplay and atmosphere outshine all of that. I have never had a stealth experience that comes anywhere close to this game or its predecessor. The game does benefit from having a fan-made patch (brings modern widescreen resolutions to the setting, allows modding and playing of fan missions and fixes a few bugs) which can be found if you go to the guides section of the community page. It goes on sale often for less than 2 dollars, this game is worth every penny. Absolutely stunning, a must have.

												It's a game where you steal stuff in a medieval steampunk setting.I recommend that you look up the plot summary of the first game before playing this game; there are a few plot points that you will miss if you don't. You can very well skip the first game and just play this one. You will miss out on the first game, but this game is the superior one, and I don't think that you'll lose too much if you play this game before the first one, save for the lockpicks not being in the first game until much later in the game.Thief 2 is a pretty old game. You'll have to re-bind controls right away (F is crouch, for example), movement is less smooth than today's games, and combat kind of sucks. Luckily, the movement is easy to get used to, and you're never supposed to engage in combat anyway.There is a bit at the end where the same map is used for 2 levels, and I'm not a fan of the final level, but the rest of the game is so excellent that it outweighs all the negatives in my eyes. Seriously, this has to be the greatest stealth game in existence. Stealth is based on line-of-sight, whether you're in a shadow or not, how much noise you're making, and even if you have something reflective in your hands. There are also a metric buttload of different entryways and routes that you can take. You could play this game over and over for years and never know about a certain ledge that you can jump on if you jump just right that gives you an entirely new perspective on a level. There are also a ton of secrets in the vein of Doom and Doom 2. The great thing about these secrets is that they're never hidden in a way that makes no sense. If there's a wall that slides away, then there's a button, or a movable torch-holder, or a bookshelf with a pullable book, or something else similar that's somewhere closeby.This is all I have to say about the gameIf you don't own it, start owning it.If you've never played it, start playing it.Unless, of course, you don't want to give money to Eidos & SqueenixThe orignal developers aren't going to see your money if you buy this, and the Thief reboot already crashed and burned, so buying this game doesn't really do anything other than give a big publisher money. The stealth genre is the only thing where this doesn\'t seem to be the case. Not to say that there aren\'t good modern day stealth games, of course there are. However, as of right now, none of them have seemed to surpass Thief 2, just offer and equally good experience, despite Thief\'s age. I won\'t go crazy on this review, but here is an example. Hitman is a stealth game of sorts, and as most games do, it discourages you from killing bad guys. The less bodies the better. How does it do this? With points, a negative effect on your over all proformance review, just some numbers on the screen. And thats all fine and dandy. But what about Thief. Thief is entirely organic, as it encourages you to be as stealthy as possible in a totally realistic way, that is much more planned out, while avoiding the whole issue of pulling you out of the experience, reminding you that \"this is just a game\".   If you encounter a guard, you could try to sneak around him. One small mistake could get you killed though, so why not knock him out? You could, but then you have to worry about the body, which if not well hiden enough, could ruin everything. Meanwhile, killing him would be even worse, since that would not only make a body, but also a blood stain, which would require a water arrow to clean. This natural progressing of actions and consequences encourages you to play with as little encounters as possible, instead guiding you to learn to sneak past guards without ever interacting with them in the first place, being the ultimate ninja. But this doesn\'t feel gamey, and doesn\'t feel arbitrary or tedious. This is just one of the many reasons why Thief 2 still stands up as a great stealth game. 												If you thought Thief Gold was pretty good, then you'll think Thief II is incredible.The Metal Age is stealth game perfection. Even though a lot of the stealth mechanics don't make much sense, such as a guard not being able to see you should you be standing inches away from them if you're in a dark spot of a brightly lit room, everything about this game is FUN. You'll spend about 40-60 minutes in each level, and that's if you're ignoring picking up all of the loot that's scattered around.The story, in comparison to the original Thief, is very well written and intriguing. The plot in the original had you fighting zombies and tomb raiding, while in this game, the focus is on the transition from a dark ages fantasy game to "The Metal Age". You don't feel so much like a spelunking knight with a sword and bow and arrow, but an actual thief, taking on bank heists and even sneaking through a medieval police station and stealing from the evidence vault. The screenshots displayed on the Store Page really don't do the game justice. For a game from 2000 the graphics have aged tremendously, and the lighting and texture work look fantastic to this day. My favorite level is the bank, just because of how spectacular the green tiled floors, wooden walkways, and red carpeted offices look. Not only do the levels look incredible, but they have some pretty great layouts and the level design is ingenious, inventive and sprawling. After replaying the bank mission so many times I've found six different ways to enter the building, and there are so many different routes you can take to get to the vault without being spotted it's insane. From crawling through a vent and dropping down into the offices adjacent to the vault room, shutting down the mechanical faces (which act as cameras hanging from the ceiling and spinning around trying to spot you) by flipping a switch on the third floor and going through the teller gates, or going through the lions den and using a rope arrow attached to the ceiling to cross the Guard's Room and into the backdoor of the vault room. I also love that each section of the immensely huge levels has a little nugget of dialogue to be heard that are entertaining to listen to and informative. The voice acting isn't great, but I always ended up quicksaving each time I heard a guard speaking with another guard so I could hear the full thing and then quickload so I didn't lose any time. What is really well done however is Garret talking to himself, usually stating the obvious but it helps players stay on track when he explains something to himself the player might not already realize. His little quips and things he says never get old, even after you've played the same level three or four times.In conclusion, this is an outstanding gem of a game that you would be doing yourself a disservice not to play.

												For Thief II, you could mostly just take my Thief Gold review, and then copy/paste all of the pros overtop of all of the cons. Thief II plays mostly the same as Thief Gold. Same graphics, same controls, same first-person view. What they did change, however, makes all the difference.Thief Gold had a number of really fun missions featuring Garrett prowling around a house or opera hall or what-have-you, knocking out guards and discovering secret passages, and those were great. But it spent just as much time knee deep in zombies, apemen, giant bugs, bugmen, ghosts, confusing labyrinths, caves, and situations where you almost HAVE to fight your way out if you're not super-great at the game.For Thief II, the devs looked at what players did and did not enjoy, and they made a game that is better in almost all respects. Save for a single Thief Gold-esque level with some apemen (which is rather forgiving compared to TG, and a fascinating level overall), there are only maybe a couple of any particular monster, and most of them are avoidable. The only new monster type I can recall gave me the biggest (and most enjoyable) fright of anything in either game. The majority of levels take place in sane man-made structures; homes, a bank, a surprisingly modern police station, and a few missions taking place across entire sections of The City. Thus the game now flows better, being less of a half-forced monster combat game, and more about sneaking around, bludgeoning unsuspecting jerks, and looting every last inch of each level.As a result of the titular Metal Age, Thief II also now includes cameras, robots, turrets,  and a selection of new tools at your disposal, such as mines and flares - the latter of which you will absolutely need, as some parts of the game can be far too dark to move around in. It's possible this is an issue on my end, or it may just be part of the game. If it's the game itself, it is one of the very few problems introduced with this installment.Also introduced, however, is a map. Though not always very helpful, it is often an invaluable tool, showing varied degrees of detail depending on the level and keeping track of where you've been and where you currently are.While the final level is complicated and confusing, most of the rest of the game is a blast. One particular element of note is the interesting play on the penultimate levels of Thief Gold. Where in TG, the three levels leading up to the final one were repeat visits to locations you had already been in previous levels, in T2 the fourth-to-last level is ALSO a repeat visit to a location you had already been in Thief Gold, now taken over by the Mechanists. The next-to-last mission is, in fact, the same location as the third-to-last mission, which somehow manages to stay fresh and fun through both levels.In the end, I heavily recommend Thief II if you enjoy stealth games. If you played Thief Gold but only sometimes liked it, I ask that you give Thief II a try instead, as it has ironed out most of the kinks. The only other thing I would like to note is that, like TFix for TG, Thief II is at its best when Tafferpatcher (a fan-made patch which improves resolution, textures, compatibility, etc.) has been applied.Now get thieving, you dirty taffer.
